thread.title: Drone footage captures Vermont fall foliage in all its glory - Vermont travel
thread.title_full: Drone footage captures Vermont fall foliage in all its glory - Vermont travel

author: boston.com
title: Drone footage captures Vermont fall foliage in all its glory - Vermont travel
text:
What better way to take in Vermont’s fall foliage than from a high flying drone (other than in person, of course).
Advertisement - Continue Reading Below Matt Benedetto filmed this video from Devil’s Hill in Groton and posted it to his Vimeo last week.
h/t Mashable
Gallery: Where to see the best New England foliage
Previous -- of -- Next Massachusetts: The Mohawk Trail region in western Mass. offers miles of winding roads with a different attraction around every corner. The road opened to the public in 1914 and today is one of the state's most popular destinations for leaf peeping. Eugene Michalenko / Photo courtesy of Mohawk Trail Previous -- of -- Next Old Sturbridge Village is located in southern Massachusetts, close to the Connecticut border. The 19th-century style living museum gives visitors a look at New England life during the early 1800s. The village is open daily from 9:30 to 5 p.m.. Photo courtesy of Worcester Chamber of Commerce Previous -- of -- Next Appleton Farms is located in Hamilton and Ipswich, about 30 miles north of Boston. The farm has been maintained by nine generations of the Appleton family. The open pastures, grasslands, livestock, and stone walls provide a perfect backdrop for autumn in New England. Photo courtesy of North of Boston Convention and Visitors Bureau Previous -- of -- Next Harold Parker State Forest spans several Massachusetts towns. The 3,000 acres sprawl across Andover, North Andover, North Reading, and Middleton, with trails for hikers and bikers to enjoy the crisp fall weather. Photo courtesy of North of Boston Convention and Visitors Bureau Previous -- of -- Next Just because Boston is a city doesn’t mean it’s not just as beautiful in the fall as the suburbs. The Boston Common, the Public Garden, and the Charles River Esplanade all offer the opportunity to be outside and enjoy the fall foliage. Photo courtesy of Greater Boston Convention and Visitors Bureau Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next New Hampshire: The White Mountains trail via the Kancamagus Highway is one of the best ways to see all the foliage New Hampshire has to offer. There are plenty of gorgeous spots along the way, like Lower Falls, to stop and see foliage and waterfalls. Photo courtesy of White Mountains New Hampshire Previous -- of -- Next Crawford Notch is along the scenic byway in Harts Location close to the Saco River. Crawford Notch State Park has almost 6,000 acres of hiking trails, waterfalls, fishing, wildlife, and spectacular mountain views. Photo courtesy of White Mountains New Hampshire Previous -- of -- Next Franconia Notch State Park in Lincoln is about two hours north of Boston, and offers beautiful views above or below the tree line. There is a Cannon Mountain aerial tramway that goes up the mountain for the best views of all the beautiful foliage. Photo courtesy of White Mountains New Hampshire Previous -- of -- Next Pinkham Notch in the White Mountains is a great starting point for an autumn hike. It provides access to the Presidential Range and the Summit of Mount Washington. There are guided walks during the fall that highlight the best spots for leaf peeping. Photo courtesy of White Mountains New Hampshire Previous -- of -- Next Mount Monadnock is located in Monadnock State Park in the southwestern part of the state close to the Vermont border. At 3,165 feet, the summit of Monadnock is perfect for looking down on to the changing trees below. Photo courtesy of NH State Parks Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Vermont: Located in southern Vermont, the town of Bennington is a great gateway to take in all the foliage the state has to offer. It’s located between the Taconic Mountains and the Green Mountains, offering numerous spots for foliage viewing. Dennis Curran / VermontVacation.com Previous -- of -- Next From late September through the first two weeks of October, the turning foliage in Vermont is in full swing. Stowe, a quintessential New England town, sits at the foot of Mount Mansfield, the highest peak in Vermont, and is beautiful place for viewing the surrounding trees. Stephen Goodhue / VermontVacation.com Previous -- of -- Next East Montpelier is nestled close to the state capital of Montpelier. Explore the town, or go for a walk in the hills to enjoy the turning leaves. The New England Culinary Institute and Cabot cheese factory are also nearby. Jim Eaton / VermontVacation.com Previous -- of -- Next Danville is a great destination for fall activities of all types. While surrounded by beautiful foliage, enjoy the "Autumn on the Green" festival or the great Vermont maze, a corn maze on 10 acres of land. Jim Eaton / VermontVacation.com Previous -- of -- Next Maine: Acadia National Park has some of the best fall foliage viewing in New England. Located right near Bar Harbor, Acadia is one of the most popular national parks in the country, attracting visitors year round. Flickr / heipei Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Camden Hills State Park offers 30 miles of hiking trails that lead to views of Camden Harbor. The park spans 5,700 acres with a variety of trails ranging in length and difficulty, and offers stunning foliage viewing. Flickr / Christopher Ramirez Previous -- of -- Next Getting to Grafton Notch State Park can be just as scenic as the hike through the park itself. The Grafton Notch scenic byway starts in Newry and follows Route 26 to the state park. Or for a longer drive, start in Naples and pass through the edge of the White Mountain National Forest. Flickr / The B’s Previous -- of -- Next Rhode Island: Newport’s Cliff Walk puts visitors right between the ocean and sprawling mansions. The public access walkway combines the natural beauty of the Newport shoreline with the architectural history of Newport's gilded age, and is a perfect setting for foliage seekers. Photo courtesy of Discover Newport Previous -- of -- Next Hopkinton is located in the southern part of the state. South County has over 100 miles of shoreline and many inland waterways that offer beautiful views. Tammy Anderson / Photo courtesy of South County Tourism Council Previous -- of -- Next Providence offers a few places to take in the fall foliage of Rhode Island. Brown University’s campus provides a nice Ivy League setting for viewing the changing landscape. Prospect Terrance Park provides an aerial view of the city to watch the sun set among the golden leaves. Flickr / Stephanie Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Blackstone Valley is a popular Rhode Island tourist destination. It offers plenty of attractions like boat tours on the river, the bike trail, or hiking in one of the valley's several parks. Flickr / H.C. Williams Previous -- of -- Next Connecticut: The historic village of Kent is a typical small New England town. The pre-Revolutionary War town sits on the edge of the Housatonic River. Kent Falls State Park offers plenty of walking trails, waterfalls, and even a covered bridge to view the colors of autumn. Flickr / Doug Kerr Previous -- of -- Next The Essex Steam Train & Riverboat Ride is a perfect way to take in all the autumn colors that southern Connecticut has to offer. The two-hour excursion takes you through the countryside and then past landmarks like Gillette Castle and the Goodspeed Opera House. Photo courtesy of Kindra Clineff Previous -- of -- Next Gouveia Vineyards in Wallingford offers views in every direction of woods, rolling hills, fields, and of course grapevines. Sit back and enjoy a crisp glass of wine while taking in the sites of the golden, orange, and red trees. Photo courtesy of Kindra Clineff Previous -- of -- Next The Roseland Cottage in Woodstock was originally built in 1846 in the fashionable Gothic Revival style. Historic New England purchased the home in 1970 and converted it into a museum. The landscaping at the sprawling estate is beautiful come the autumn months. Photo courtesy of Kindra Clineff Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement
